title: Untitled
text: You can refund non-disputed payments to your customers using the Stripe API or directly from the Dashboard. When setting the amount of the refund, adjust the input so it is not a full amount. The steps are the same as a full refund, which can be followed here .

title: Untitled
text: This page contains information intended for customers of businesses that use Stripe. If your business uses Stripe and you’d like to find out more about disputes, please see our article on the refund process .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe is unable to issue refunds on behalf of businesses using Stripe to accept payments. To initiate an exchange or refund, customers will need to reach out to the business directly.

title: Untitled
text: If you are unable to get in touch with the business or they are unresponsive, the next course of action would be to reach out to your bank for options. They may have recommendations for how to proceed, such as opening a dispute .

title: Untitled
text: If you expect an increase in customer refunds or disputes, you can proactively add money to your Stripe account to avoid a negative balance and prevent business disruptions and chargebacks.

title: Untitled
text: Follow our detailed instructions on adding funds directly to your Stripe account from the Dashboard. Adding funds directly is not supported in India or Brazil.

title: Untitled
text: If you are in a country where Stripe supports automatic withdrawal for negative balances, check your balance and future payouts before adding additional funds in case your negative balance was already addressed.

title: Untitled
text: If you are in a country where topping up your payments balance directly is not allowed, funds will be credited to a separate balance type called Future refunds or disputes (FROD) on your Balances page . The funds in this balance are solely used for future refunds and disputes. Your existing pending refunds will be released after Stripe automatically sweeps funds from the FROD balance to recover your negative balance.

title: Untitled
text: Automatic withdrawal, or auto debits, is when Stripe initiates an account debit from the bank account on file for the negative balance. This is helpful to maintain a funded and operational account without the need for manual intervention, streamlining your overall financial management.

title: Untitled
text: If your account is eligible for automatic withdrawal, Stripe will attempt to debit your bank account within 2 business days of the negative balance. If the debit is successful, your account will be funded, and can continue processing transactions. However, if the debit fails, funds need to be added to your Stripe balance using an alternative method, such as a manual transfer or a credit card.

title: Untitled
text: If you have multiple different bank accounts in different currencies, the balance for each currency is handled separately. Stripe will not subtract from payments received in one currency to cover a negative balance in another currency.

title: Untitled
text: If cancellation is still possible, card refunds must be cancelled using the Dashboard and the refund must not have been processed as a charge reversal.

title: Untitled
text: To cancel a refund from the Dashboard , go to the Payments tab. Either click a specific payment and cancel the refund from its details page, or alternately:

title: Untitled
text: For refunds where we reach out to the customer for their bank account details through email, the refund can only be canceled before the customer submits their bank account details through the refund input link, or in case of refund attempt failure or retry. If the refund can still be canceled, initiate the cancellation through the API .

title: Untitled
text: If cancellation is no longer available, you need to create a new charge for the customer in the amount of the refund in order to recoup the funds.

title: Untitled
text: A reversal can occur if a refund is submitted soon after the original charge. This means the original charge will drop off the bank statement as if it never occurred, and the bank account balance adjusts to credit that money back without a specific line item on the statement.

title: Untitled
text: A partial refund made soon after the original charge can be processed as a partial reversal. The original charge will be replaced with a lower amount on the customer’s bank statement instead of a separate line item refund.

title: Untitled
text: The refund hasn't been initiated either because the customer’s bank is still processing it, or because there is an insufficient balance in your Stripe account. Hover over the Refund Pending status in the Dashboard Payments tab to determine why the refund is pending. Learn how to Fix your pending refund or more about Understanding refund statuses .

title: Untitled
text: If your customer doesn't see a credit or adjustment and they still see the original charge after 10 business days, they should reach out to their bank for more information.

title: Untitled
text: For card refunds, you can provide them with ARNs or STANs to share with their bank for tracing purposes .

title: Untitled
text: To help a customer asking for the status of their refund, you can provide the Acquirer Reference Number (ARN) which allows them to work with their bank to trace the refund for all Visa and Mastercard charges. System Trace Audit Numbers (STANs) are sometimes required to track the status of a refund, such as with reversals . Some networks don't support ARN, so you'd provide your customers the Retrieval Reference Number (RRN) if available. You only need one of the above references in order to track your refund.

title: Untitled
text: On your Dashboard on the Transactions page and Payments tab, select a specific transaction and find its Timeline section to locate the reference number. If it's not there, click View details under the refund entry to open the top-up window that displays the reference number.

title: Untitled
text: If the reference number isn't in either of the above locations, you should see a message that the reference number will be available in 1-3 business days.

title: Untitled
text: An ARN is a unique number assigned to a credit card transaction as it moves through the payment flow. It can be used by banks to help trace your refund if it appears to be missing. An ARN will be available only for supported card networks, and marked as unavailable otherwise.

title: Untitled
text: A STAN is a number generated by the cardholder bank that can be used to identify a transaction. STAN is a trace ID number most commonly used internally at the cardholders bank. It’s always a six-digit code, and therefore is not truly unique as the code resets after 999,999.

title: Untitled
text: An RRN is a 12-character identifier to a card transaction based on the ISO 8583 standard. The standard format for an RRN includes the date and hour of the authorization, making it somewhat unique. For some networks that do not support ARN, a RRN will be provided if it is available.

title: Untitled
text: Because STANs are six digit codes, they aren't truly unique but are useful when ARNs aren't available in cases such as reversals. Depending on network supportability, sometimes an RRN is provided instead of ARN. An RRN is somewhat unique and often useful to track single message network transactions.

title: Untitled
text: Some local payment methods, like SEPA Direct Debit, offer refund references which can also be found on the Dashboard if available.

title: Untitled
text: In most cases, the bank will redirect the refund to your customer’s new or replacement card. If your customer does not have a new card, the bank will usually send the refund directly to their bank account.

title: Untitled
text: If neither of those options are available, the bank will return the money to Stripe and we will contact you via email for further action.

title: Untitled
text: For businesses on IC+ pricing, depending on your fee schedule with Stripe, there may be some fees for issuing refunds. For all other businesses, there may be fees when bank transfers are used. For all other payment methods, there are no fees for issuing refunds. The payment processing, Connect, and currency conversion fees from the original charge are not returned.

title: Untitled
text: A large portion of the underlying cost of payment processing is driven by fees assessed by banks and payment networks (like Visa and Mastercard). These networks set rules about which fees apply for refunded payments, and in many cases banks and card networks keep the entire upfront cost of a refunded transaction. For some regions and payment types, refunded payments also incur additional fees.

title: Untitled
text: We aim to make our pricing simple and transparent, and our standard fees include access to a variety of features like fraud protection, reporting, and other tools for managing your payments. To address these underlying payment processing costs and continue providing these services as part of our standard pricing, Stripe does not return our fees when a payment is refunded.

title: Untitled
text: Even if the account has been closed, the account owner will still be responsible for any refunds that are issued or any disputes that arise.

title: Untitled
text: Due to this, it is normally suggested to leave the account dormant rather than closing it altogether, as this makes it easier to be responsive if these situations occur.

title: Untitled
text: If you have received a dispute for the full amount of a charge that you have partially refunded the customer for, provide evidence of the partial refund in your dispute response evidence submission. This should include the amount and date of the refund, and a screenshot of the refund information from your Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: Card issuers have processes in place to rectify this. In most cases, the card issuer will cancel the original dispute and then create a separate dispute for the corrected amount.

title: Untitled
text: Even if you plan to accept the unrefunded portion of the dispute, it is important to provide evidence of the partial refund in your dispute response submission.

title: Untitled
text: In Stripe, the dispute is used to track the overall outcome. If the dispute is fully resolved in your favor, the entire amount is returned to you. If it is not, only the partially refunded amount is returned. In this case, the dispute’s status is set to lost , and in the Dashboard, the dispute is shown as “partially won”.

title: Untitled
text: For businesses on IC+ pricing, depending on your fee schedule with Stripe, there may be some fees for issuing refunds. For all other businesses, there may be fees when bank transfers are used. For all other payment methods, there are no fees for issuing refunds. The payment processing, Connect, and currency conversion fees from the original charge are not returned.

title: Untitled
text: A large portion of the underlying cost of payment processing is driven by fees assessed by banks and payment networks (like Visa and Mastercard). These networks set rules about which fees apply for refunded payments, and in many cases banks and card networks keep the entire upfront cost of a refunded transaction. For some regions and payment types, refunded payments also incur additional fees.

title: Untitled
text: We aim to make our pricing simple and transparent, and our standard fees include access to a variety of features like fraud protection, reporting, and other tools for managing your payments. To address these underlying payment processing costs and continue providing these services as part of our standard pricing, Stripe does not return our fees when a payment is refunded.

title: Untitled
text: If cancellation is still possible, card refunds must be cancelled using the Dashboard and the refund must not have been processed as a charge reversal.

title: Untitled
text: To cancel a refund from the Dashboard , go to the Payments tab. Either click a specific payment and cancel the refund from its details page, or alternately:

title: Untitled
text: For refunds where we reach out to the customer for their bank account details through email, the refund can only be canceled before the customer submits their bank account details through the refund input link, or in case of refund attempt failure or retry. If the refund can still be canceled, initiate the cancellation through the API .

title: Untitled
text: If cancellation is no longer available, you need to create a new charge for the customer in the amount of the refund in order to recoup the funds.

title: Dispute process
text: This page contains information intended for customers of businesses that use Stripe. If your business uses Stripe and you’d like to find out more about disputes, please see our article on the dispute process and submitting evidence .

title: Dispute process
text: Disputes, also known as chargebacks, are a feature of the Visa, Mastercard, and American Express card networks intended to protect you, the cardholder, from fraudulent activity (e.g., following a theft or card cloning). The dispute process can also be used to reverse authorized card payments in justified cases of breaches of consumer rights.

title: Dispute process
text: Before filing a dispute with your bank, it’s important that you exhaust any and all means of contacting the business you’re dealing with to resolve the issue amicably. If the business is unresponsive, or if you are not satisfied with their handling of your refund request, you can contact your bank to explore further options, including filing a dispute.

title: Dispute process
text: Note: The outcome of a dispute is decided upon entirely by your bank—Stripe has no involvement in this decision. To inquire about the status or outcome of a dispute, you will need to contact your bank.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe may debit a user's bank account if their balance goes negative to ensure timely refunds and reduce customer disputes.

title: Untitled
text: A Standard Stripe account is a conventional Stripe account controlled directly by the account holder. A user with a Standard account is able to log in to the Dashboard , can process charges on their own, and can disconnect their account from a platform. You are also a Standard account if you are a Connect platform.

title: Untitled
text: We may debit your bank account if your Stripe balance goes into the negative. We do this to ensure that any pending refunds on your Stripe account can be fulfilled in a timely manner, which will reduce the risk of customer disputes.

title: Untitled
text: Your available Stripe balance may go into the negative if the cost of refunds, disputes, or Stripe fees is greater than the existing balance. If your Stripe account has a negative balance, you won’t be able to issue refunds until the balance is returned to a positive state.

title: Untitled
text: As noted in the Stripe Services Agreement , you agree to allow Stripe to debit funds from your bank account to cover amounts you owe to Stripe. This includes negative balances on your Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: It’s important that we ensure your account does not hold a negative balance for long periods of time, as it may delay refunds to your customers, which could result in disputes and related fees.

title: Untitled
text: Continuous disputes may result in your business being added to a card network monitoring program . For this reason, we need to initiate the debit as a response to a negative balance.

title: Untitled
text: The debit attempt will fail, and you may incur an overdraft or dishonor fee depending on your bank’s policies. We will make multiple subsequent attempts to debit your bank account in the event that a debit fails, so we strongly advise you to ensure you have enough funds in your bank account to cover the debit amount.

title: Untitled
text: Yes. You can change your bank account by updating the bank account linked to your Stripe account via the Dashboard. This will also change the bank account to which your payouts are sent.

title: Untitled
text: Note that updating your bank account does not affect Stripe's ability to debit the prior bank account under the SSA.

title: Untitled
text: Standard Stripe accounts will only be debited if their negative balance is greater than 10 units of their local currency (e.g., 10 USD, 10 GBP, 10 EUR, etc.).

title: Untitled
text: After the negative payout has been created on your Dashboard, you should expect the debits to take place as follows:

title: Untitled
text: For the best estimate as to when the funds will be debited from your bank account, you can check the ‘Expected by’ date of the payout on your Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: You may need to authorize Stripe to debit your US bank account. To do this, you will need to contact your bank directly and provide them with our ACH company IDs .

title: Untitled
text: If you see the Direct debit guarantee details, then the instructions are active and your account can be automatically debited to remedy a negative balance.

title: Untitled
text: It can take up to 3 days for the DDI instructions to show up on a newly added bank account.

title: Untitled
text: If your business has a bank account that requires two or more signatories to allow the account to be debited and you are in the United Kingdom (UK), contact Stripe Support for a paper Direct Debit Instruction form to sign and return.

title: Untitled
text: Refunds move through multiple statuses before successfully reconciling to the customer’s balance. You might need to take action for certain types of statuses.

title: Untitled
text: The refund has been successfully initiated from Stripe. This doesn't guarantee that the refund has landed on the customer’s side. After the required processing time of 5-10 business days, your customer should receive their refund.

title: Untitled
text: In the Dashboard Payments tab, click the transaction to view more details about it. If available, find the reference number by clicking View Details under the Timeline .

title: Untitled
text: The refund has been initiated as a reversal . The original payment will not show up on your customer's bank statement. The status is usually accompanied by a System Trace Audit Number (STAN) on the Dashboard payment page for the transaction.

title: Untitled
text: These are similar to Refunded and Reversed, except the refund that's been initiated is for part of the original transaction amount. To see the refunded amount, go to the Dashboard Payments tab and hover over the info icon of the transaction.

title: Untitled
text: The refund hasn't been initiated for one of the following three reasons. Hover over the Refund Pending status in the Dashboard Payments tab to determine the reason the refund is pending.

title: Untitled
text: Some refunds are pending while our financial partner or customer’s bank is processing them. You don't need to take any further action.

title: Untitled
text: Some refunds are pending because the refunding payment is still processing and has not been settled. You don’t need to take any further action.

title: Untitled
text: The refund is pending due to an insufficient balance in your Stripe account. To unblock the refund process, follow the steps in Fix your pending refund .

title: Untitled
text: Normally, your pending refunds are automatically released when future payments are processed to offset your negative balance. However, the future payment volume may not always be sufficient. Follow the steps in Fix the negative balance on your account to proactively top up or set up auto debit, or if you’re in a country where you can’t directly top up your payment balance, wait for Stripe to move funds from your Future refunds or disputes (FROD) balance.

title: Untitled
text: Funds availability timing. Funds typically become available and show up in your balance within 3 to 7 business days, depending on the method used to add funds. Note that after the refund is released, it takes 5-10 additional days for the banks to settle refunds with the end customers.

title: Untitled
text: Pending refunds in different currencies. A pending refund will not be released unless the balance of the refund settlement currency is sufficient and the overall balance is sufficient. If the refund is settled in the non-default currency, you must also Fix the negative balance on your account .

title: Untitled
text: Whether a refund is put into pending depends on the type of Connect set-ups . Follow the Stripe docs to determine the ultimate responsibility and take the right actions to manage your connected account’s negative balances.

title: Untitled
text: To help a customer asking for the status of their refund, you can provide the Acquirer Reference Number (ARN) which allows them to work with their bank to trace the refund for all Visa and Mastercard charges. System Trace Audit Numbers (STANs) are sometimes required to track the status of a refund, such as with reversals . Some networks don't support ARN, so you'd provide your customers the Retrieval Reference Number (RRN) if available. You only need one of the above references in order to track your refund.

title: Untitled
text: On your Dashboard on the Transactions page and Payments tab, select a specific transaction and find its Timeline section to locate the reference number. If it's not there, click View details under the refund entry to open the top-up window that displays the reference number.

title: Untitled
text: If the reference number isn't in either of the above locations, you should see a message that the reference number will be available in 1-3 business days.

text: An ARN is a unique number assigned to a credit card transaction as it moves through the payment flow. It can be used by banks to help trace your refund if it appears to be missing. An ARN will be available only for supported card networks, and marked as unavailable otherwise.

title: Untitled
text: A STAN is a number generated by the cardholder bank that can be used to identify a transaction. STAN is a trace ID number most commonly used internally at the cardholders bank. It’s always a six-digit code, and therefore is not truly unique as the code resets after 999,999.

title: Untitled
text: An RRN is a 12-character identifier to a card transaction based on the ISO 8583 standard. The standard format for an RRN includes the date and hour of the authorization, making it somewhat unique. For some networks that do not support ARN, a RRN will be provided if it is available.

title: Untitled
text: Because STANs are six digit codes, they aren't truly unique but are useful when ARNs aren't available in cases such as reversals. Depending on network supportability, sometimes an RRN is provided instead of ARN. An RRN is somewhat unique and often useful to track single message network transactions.

title: Untitled
text: A partial refund made soon after the original charge can be processed as a partial reversal. The original charge will be replaced with a lower amount on the customer’s bank statement instead of a separate line item refund.

title: Untitled

Hover over the Refund Pending status in the Dashboard Payments tab to determine why the refund is pending. Learn how to Fix your pending refund or more about Understanding refund statuses .

title: Untitled

title: Untitled
text: Some local payment methods, like SEPA Direct Debit, offer refund references which can also be found on the Dashboard if available.

title: Untitled
text: A dispute (also known as a chargeback) occurs when a cardholder questions your payment with their card issuer.  The dispute process and timeline varies by card network, but typically follows this process .

title: Untitled
text: Every new dispute is assigned a reason code . If you believe the dispute's reason is incorrect or want to challenge the dispute, upload evidence supporting why the payment was valid through the Dashboard or via the API . Stripe sends submitted evidence to the card issuer for their review.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe may debit a user's bank account if their balance goes negative to ensure timely refunds and reduce customer disputes.

title: Untitled
text: A Standard Stripe account is a conventional Stripe account controlled directly by the account holder. A user with a Standard account is able to log in to the Dashboard , can process charges on their own, and can disconnect their account from a platform. You are also a Standard account if you are a Connect platform.

title: Untitled

title: Untitled
text: As noted in the Stripe Services Agreement , you agree to allow Stripe to debit funds from your bank account to cover amounts you owe to Stripe. This includes negative balances on your Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: It’s important that we ensure your account does not hold a negative balance for long periods of time, as it may delay refunds to your customers, which could result in disputes and related fees.

title: Untitled
text: Continuous disputes may result in your business being added to a card network monitoring program . For this reason, we need to initiate the debit as a response to a negative balance.

title: Untitled
text: The debit attempt will fail, and you may incur an overdraft or dishonor fee depending on your bank’s policies. We will make multiple subsequent attempts to debit your bank account in the event that a debit fails, so we strongly advise you to ensure you have enough funds in your bank account to cover the debit amount.

title: Untitled
text: Note that updating your bank account does not affect Stripe's ability to debit the prior bank account under the SSA.

title: Untitled

title: Untitled
text: After the negative payout has been created on your Dashboard, you should expect the debits to take place as follows:

title: Untitled
text: For the best estimate as to when the funds will be debited from your bank account, you can check the ‘Expected by’ date of the payout on your Dashboard.

We will make multiple subsequent attempts to debit your bank account in the event that a debit fails, so we strongly advise you to ensure you have enough funds in your bank account to cover the debit amount.

title: Untitled
text: Yes. You can change your bank account by updating the bank account linked to your Stripe account via the Dashboard. This will also change the bank account to which your payouts are sent.

title: Untitled
text: Note that updating your bank account does not affect Stripe's ability to debit the prior bank account under the SSA.

title: Untitled
text: Standard Stripe accounts will only be debited if their negative balance is greater than 10 units of their local currency (e.g., 10 USD, 10 GBP, 10 EUR, etc.).

title: Untitled
text: After the negative payout has been created on your Dashboard, you should expect the debits to take place as follows:

title: Untitled
text: For the best estimate as to when the funds will be debited from your bank account, you can check the ‘Expected by’ date of the payout on your Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: You may need to authorize Stripe to debit your US bank account. To do this, you will need to contact your bank directly and provide them with our ACH company IDs .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe may debit a user's bank account if their balance goes negative to ensure timely refunds and reduce customer disputes.

title: Untitled
text: A Standard Stripe account is a conventional Stripe account controlled directly by the account holder. A user with a Standard account is able to log in to the Dashboard , can process charges on their own, and can disconnect their account from a platform. You are also a Standard account if you are a Connect platform.

title: Untitled
text: We may debit your bank account if your Stripe balance goes into the negative. We do this to ensure that any pending refunds on your Stripe account can be fulfilled in a timely manner, which will reduce the risk of customer disputes.

title: Untitled
text: Your available Stripe balance may go into the negative if the cost of refunds, disputes, or Stripe fees is greater than the existing balance. If your Stripe account has a negative balance, you won’t be able to issue refunds until the balance is returned to a positive state.

title: Untitled
text: As noted in the Stripe Services Agreement , you agree to allow Stripe to debit funds from your bank account to cover amounts you owe to Stripe. This includes negative balances on your Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: It’s important that we ensure your account does not hold a negative balance for long periods of time, as it may delay refunds to your customers, which could result in disputes and related fees.

title: Untitled
text: Continuous disputes may result in your business being added to a card network monitoring program . For this reason, we need to initiate the debit as a response to a negative balance.

title: Untitled
text: The debit attempt will fail, and you may incur an overdraft or dishonor fee depending on your bank’s policies. We will make multiple subsequent attempts to debit your bank account in the event that a debit fails, so we strongly advise you to ensure you have enough funds in your bank account to cover the debit amount.

title: Untitled
text: After the negative payout has been created on your Dashboard, you should expect the debits to take place as follows:

title: Untitled
text: For the best estimate as to when the funds will be debited from your bank account, you can check the ‘Expected by’ date of the payout on your Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: You may need to authorize Stripe to debit your US bank account. To do this, you will need to contact your bank directly and provide them with our ACH company IDs .

title: Untitled
text: An ACH company ID is a 10-digit identifier used by banks and Nacha, the operator of the ACH network, to identify the entity collecting payments or sending money via ACH (also referred to as an “originator”).

title: Untitled
text: Company IDs help ensure that debits are made on the correct bank account since some business bank accounts may have filters in place to deny debits from unknown entities. To allow Stripe to debit from or deposit into your (or your customer's) account on your behalf, Stripe's ACH company IDs must be provided to the bank to ensure ACH transactions will be processed.

title: Untitled
text: In some cases, a debit that is attempted on such an account without providing Stripe's ACH company IDs will result in an unexpected dispute. When this happens, the bank account may also become blocked for use with Stripe.

title: Untitled
text: If you expect an increase in customer refunds or disputes, you can proactively add money to your Stripe account to avoid a negative balance and prevent business disruptions and chargebacks.

title: Untitled
text: Follow our detailed instructions on adding funds directly to your Stripe account from the Dashboard. Adding funds directly is not supported in India or Brazil.

title: Untitled
text: If you are in a country where Stripe supports automatic withdrawal for negative balances, check your balance and future payouts before adding additional funds in case your negative balance was already addressed.

title: Untitled
text: If you are in a country where topping up your payments balance directly is not allowed, funds will be credited to a separate balance type called Future refunds or disputes (FROD) on your Balances page . The funds in this balance are solely used for future refunds and disputes. Your existing pending refunds will be released after Stripe automatically sweeps funds from the FROD balance to recover your negative balance.

title: Untitled
text: Automatic withdrawal, or auto debits, is when Stripe initiates an account debit from the bank account on file for the negative balance. This is helpful to maintain a funded and operational account without the need for manual intervention, streamlining your overall financial management.

title: Untitled
text: If your account is eligible for automatic withdrawal, Stripe will attempt to debit your bank account within 2 business days of the negative balance. If the debit is successful, your account will be funded, and can continue processing transactions. However, if the debit fails, funds need to be added to your Stripe balance using an alternative method, such as a manual transfer or a credit card.

title: Untitled
text: If you have multiple different bank accounts in different currencies, the balance for each currency is handled separately. Stripe will not subtract from payments received in one currency to cover a negative balance in another currency.

title: Untitled
text: Bank account details can be updated at any time. However, if a payout is already in transit, it will be paid out to the previous bank account and not to the new one.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe creates payouts in advance of their post date to ensure that funds reach your bank account on the date that they are expected. If there is a payout showing in your Dashboard as “n transit” or “paid” any changes to your bank account information will not retroactively apply to these payouts and will only apply to the next payout.

title: Untitled
text: Payouts are sent to the bank account on file at the time the payout is initiated. If that account is closed, banks will then either inform Stripe that the bank account is closed and return the funds to your account automatically or contact you directly to disperse the funds. It can take up to 5 business days for the money to be returned to Stripe.

title: Untitled
text: You should contact your old bank to understand what will happen to the funds. You will need to provide the following information: bank account details, date expected, exact amount, and payor (Stripe). You can find these details at the Dashboard .

title: Untitled
text: If you haven’t received a payment, it’s possible the bank details were entered incorrectly (either a typo or not the account you thought it would go to). Go to the Settings page of the Dashboard , select Business Settings , and correct your bank details if necessary .

title: Untitled
text: If the bank account information added to your Stripe account exists (the account number and/or routing number exist) at the time the payout went "in transit", your payouts was sent there.

title: Untitled
text: If your payout is missing or has failed, you may have received an email with the subject line “Action required to resume payouts from your Stripe balance”, stating that “Your bank notified us that they could not process this payout” with a call to action to update your bank account. This  indicates that your bank account may have been denylisted due to an underlying issue, such as:

title: Untitled
text: Confirm that the bank account details associated with your Stripe account are correct. Then, work with your bank to ensure that your account is active, the bank details are correct, and the bank has allowlisted Stripe’s ACH IDs . After you've confirmed these details with your bank, if you're still unable to pay out to this bank account, contact Stripe Support with one of the following required documentation:

title: Untitled
text: An ACH company ID is a 10-digit identifier used by banks and Nacha, the operator of the ACH network, to identify the entity collecting payments or sending money via ACH (also referred to as an “originator”).

title: Untitled
text: Company IDs help ensure that debits are made on the correct bank account since some business bank accounts may have filters in place to deny debits from unknown entities. To allow Stripe to debit from or deposit into your (or your customer's) account on your behalf, Stripe's ACH company IDs must be provided to the bank to ensure ACH transactions will be processed.

title: Untitled
text: In some cases, a debit that is attempted on such an account without providing Stripe's ACH company IDs will result in an unexpected dispute. When this happens, the bank account may also become blocked for use with Stripe.
